Agincourt is one of the most evocative names in English military history.
Shakespeare's version of King Henry V's speech before the battle is not only great theater, but a scene summoned as recently as the Second World War to boost British morale.
When English and French forces lined up against each other on St. Crispin's Day in 1415, that famous band of brothers was exhausted, hungry, sick with dysentery, and vastly outnumbered.

And while the battle continues to echo through history, there remains a great deal of confusion about where it happened exactly, how the English pulled off their remarkable victory, even what day of the week it happened on.
Juliet Barker's new book, Agincourt: King Henry V and the Battle That Made England, addresses many of these questions.
The author joins us now from the studios of the BBC in Leeds.
Thanks very much for being with us today.
It's my pleasure.
